title: 113_hr4756
content: The Act is titled the "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act." It amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying, mandating employees to report bullying incidents within 7 business days, detailing the acts, protected characteristics involved, and the response by the educational agency. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying for employees of local educational agencies. An exception is made for employees who are informed of bullying by a student but the student requests that it not be reported. The agency must designate an individual to receive reports of bullying and inform all employees of the contact information. Within 60 days of receiving a report, the designated individual must inform all employees of the acts described and the response by the agency. The BRAVE Act amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying for employees of local educational agencies. Within 60 days of receiving a report, the designated individual must inform all employees of the acts described and the response by the agency. The agency must publish quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying and employee responses, excluding any personally identifiable student information. The BRAVE Act amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying for employees of local educational agencies. Each agency must annually review bullying policies and certify compliance with the Secretary to receive funding under this Act. The BRAVE Act requires local educational agencies to certify compliance with bullying reporting requirements to receive federal funding. The Assistant Secretary of Education must establish a procedure for complaints related to non-compliance and publish it on the Department of Education's website. The Assistant Secretary of Education must investigate complaints to determine if a local educational agency failed to comply with bullying reporting requirements. If non-compliance is found, actions may include withholding funds, issuing a cease and desist order, or entering into a compliance agreement. The Assistant Secretary of Education can take actions such as withholding funds, issuing a cease and desist order, or entering into a compliance agreement with a local educational agency to address non-compliance with bullying reporting requirements. Information about complaints must be made public on the Department of Education's website within 60 days, excluding any personally identifiable student information. The definition of bullying includes severe, pervasive, or persistent acts causing harm or concern towards another student, leading them to withdraw from school activities. Protected characteristics encompass race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation.
